questions.text: Does the company produce an approved annual budget before the fiscal year begins?
questions.help: An approved budget provides a baseline for performance measurement. Without it, you cannot effectively track variance or hold teams accountable for spending.

expert_action.title: Implement Annual Budget Cycle
expert_action.recommendation: Establish a formal budget calendar working backwards 3-4 months. Crucially, secure explicit leadership sponsorship to enforce deadlines. Assign clear ownership for timeline management.

questions.text: Does the budget include a full P&L down to Net Income (not just Revenue/Opex)?
questions.help: Tracking only Revenue and OpEx ignores critical costs like interest and taxes. A full P&L view ensures you are managing true profitability, not just operational margin.

expert_action.title: Extend Budget to Full P&L
expert_action.recommendation: Add interest expense, tax provision, and below-the-line items to your budget template. Even rough estimates are better than ignoring these lines.

questions.text: Can every line of budgeted OpEx be mapped to a specific human owner (e.g., department head)?
questions.help: When 'everyone' owns a budget line, no one does. Mapping costs to specific owners ensures accountability and gives you a direct point of contact for variance investigation.

expert_action.title: Assign Budget Ownership
expert_action.recommendation: Create a simple RACI matrix mapping every cost center to a named owner. Publish it. Make budget reviews part of their job description.

questions.text: Do department heads formally sign off on their budget numbers before the year starts?
questions.help: Formal sign-off prevents the common excuse of 'Finance gave me this number.' It forces operational leaders to validate and commit to their targets.

expert_action.title: Implement Budget Sign-Off
expert_action.recommendation: Add a formal sign-off step before budget consolidation. Can be as simple as email confirmation, but documented.

questions.text: Is there a single person clearly accountable for the integrity and delivery of the end-to-end budget process?
questions.help: A budget process with shared ownership often leads to missed deadlines and version control errors. A single process owner ensures coordination and quality control.

expert_action.title: Assign Budget Process Owner
expert_action.recommendation: Name one person accountable for budget timeline, templates, and consolidation. Doesn't need to be senior—needs to be organized and empowered.

questions.text: Is there a formally approved budget policy that defines roles, timelines, and approval thresholds for the annual budget process?
questions.help: Documented policies reduce ambiguity. They clarify who has the authority to approve spending and what steps must be followed, preventing ad-hoc decision making.

expert_action.title: Create Budget Policy
expert_action.recommendation: Draft a simple 2-page policy defining who approves what. Ensure it covers reallocations and 'use-it-or-lose-it' rules.

questions.text: Is there a single, documented chart of accounts used by all business units?
questions.help: A unified chart of accounts is the foundation of comparable reporting. Without it, consolidating data across business units becomes manual, error-prone, and slow.

expert_action.title: Standardize Chart of Accounts
expert_action.recommendation: Document your canonical CoA. Identify and map local variations. Create governance for new account requests.

questions.text: Are new GL account requests reviewed by a central controller before creation?
questions.help: Uncontrolled creation of GL accounts leads to data clutter and inconsistent reporting. Central review ensures new accounts are necessary and properly classified.

expert_action.title: Centralize GL Creation
expert_action.recommendation: Lock down the ERP. Only a central data steward (or Controller) should have rights to create new accounts.

questions.text: Are spending approvals systematically rejected by Finance when they exceed delegated authority, without escalation to override the controls?
questions.help: Controls are only effective if enforced consistently. Allowing overrides weakens the control environment and signals that policies are optional.

expert_action.title: Automate Approval Matrix
expert_action.recommendation: Build the delegation of authority (DOA) into the ERP or procurement tool. Remove 'email approval' options.

questions.text: Does the system prevent a PO from being raised if there is no remaining budget (hard or soft block)?
questions.help: Preventative controls are cheaper than detective ones. Stopping unbudgeted spend before it happens is more effective than explaining a variance after the fact.

expert_action.title: Enable System Budget Control
expert_action.recommendation: Turn on 'Encumbrance Accounting' or budget checks in your PO system. Start with a soft warning before moving to hard blocks.

questions.text: Is the month-end close checklist documented and signed off each period?
questions.help: A documented checklist ensures all necessary steps are completed for a reliable close. Sign-offs provide an audit trail and accountability for task completion.

expert_action.title: Implement Close Checklist
expert_action.recommendation: Use a shared tool (Excel or specialised software) to list every close task. Review status daily during close week.

questions.text: Is there a formal 'hard close' of the books that prevents back-dated entries without Controller approval?
questions.help: Allowing back-dated entries compromises historical data integrity. A hard close ensures that once a period is reported, the numbers remain static and reliable.

expert_action.title: Implement Hard Close
expert_action.recommendation: Configure your ERP to automatically lock accounting periods 3-5 days after month-end. Require CFO override for exceptions.

questions.text: Is a standard monthly management reporting package distributed to leadership?
questions.help: Consistent reporting builds trust. A standard package ensures leadership receives the same key information each month, allowing for trend analysis and informed decision-making.

expert_action.title: Standardize Monthly Pack
expert_action.recommendation: Create a template that doesn't change month-to-month. Include: Executive Summary, P&L, KPIs, Capex, and Headcount.

questions.text: Do functional leaders use the management report as the primary data source for their own internal performance reviews?
questions.help: If leaders rely on their own 'shadow' spreadsheets, finance reports become irrelevant. Adoption of the central report as the single source of truth aligns the organization.

expert_action.title: Drive Adoption via Reviews
expert_action.recommendation: Sit in on functional QBRs. If they use their own spreadsheets instead of your deck, ask 'why?'. Fix the gap.

questions.text: Is a Budget vs. Actuals (BvA) report generated every month?
questions.help: Regular BvA analysis identifies where the business is deviating from plan. It is the primary tool for catching overspend and understanding performance drivers.

expert_action.title: Implement Monthly BvA
expert_action.recommendation: Make BvA the heartbeat of finance. If it's not produced, the month isn't closed.

questions.text: Are BvA reports distributed to budget owners within 5 business days of month-end close?
questions.help: Speed is critical for relevance. Delivering reports weeks after the month end reduces their value, as it's too late to influence the current month's actions.

expert_action.title: Accelerate BvA Distribution
expert_action.recommendation: Automate the distribution. If you are copy-pasting into emails, you are too slow.

questions.text: Are variances exceeding a defined threshold formally investigated?
questions.help: Investigating significant variances separates noise from signal. Formal thresholds ensure focus is placed on material deviations that require explanation.

expert_action.title: Institutionalize Variance Reviews
expert_action.recommendation: Set the rule: >10% variance requires a written comment. No comment = incomplete report.

questions.text: Does the monthly review meeting result in documented action items for significant variances?
questions.help: Analysis without action is wasted effort. Documenting action items ensures that insights from variance analysis lead to corrective measures.

expert_action.title: Track Variance Actions
expert_action.recommendation: Maintain an 'Action Log' from the review meeting. 'John to investigate $50k software overspend by Friday.' Check it next month.

questions.text: Is a full P&L re-forecast completed at least quarterly?
questions.help: An annual budget becomes obsolete quickly. Quarterly re-forecasting allows the business to adjust resource allocation based on actual year-to-date performance.

expert_action.title: Implement Quarterly Reforecast
expert_action.recommendation: Move from annual budget to 3+9, 6+6, 9+3 forecasts. Update the view based on YTD reality.

questions.text: Does the rolling forecast extend beyond the current fiscal year end?
questions.help: Business doesn't stop at year-end. A rolling forecast (e.g., 12 months out) provides continuous visibility, aiding in longer-term decision making.

expert_action.title: Extend Forecast Horizon
expert_action.recommendation: Add 4 quarters to your view. Don't fall off a cliff at year-end.

questions.text: Does the forecast project cash flow and liquidity, not just P&L?
questions.help: Profit is not cash. Forecasting liquidity ensures the business can meet its obligations and fund operations, which is critical for survival and growth.

expert_action.title: Add Cash Flow to Forecast
expert_action.recommendation: Build a 13-week cash flow model alongside your P&L forecast. Start with direct method: receipts and payments.

questions.text: Are working capital assumptions (DSO, DPO) explicitly modeled in the forecast?
questions.help: Working capital drivers directly impact cash flow. Modeling them explicitly allows you to see the cash impact of operational changes like collecting faster or paying slower.

expert_action.title: Model Working Capital Drivers
expert_action.recommendation: Don't just plug cash. Driver-based AR (Sales * DSO) and AP (COGS * DPO) gives you levers to pull.

questions.text: Is the live forecast stored in a multi-user system rather than offline Excel files?
questions.help: Offline spreadsheets are prone to version errors and breakage. A multi-user system ensures a single source of truth and allows for real-time collaboration.

expert_action.title: Migrate to Collaborative Planning
expert_action.recommendation: Invest in dedicated FP&A software (e.g., DataRails, Planful). If not feasible, move to cloud sheets with strict version control. Stop single-user files.

questions.text: Can multiple users update their forecast inputs simultaneously without version conflicts?
questions.help: Simultaneous access speeds up the planning cycle. It prevents the bottleneck of waiting for one person to finish before another can start.

expert_action.title: Implement Concurrent Planning
expert_action.recommendation: Enable 'sheet protection' or database-level locking so Sales can update Revenue while HR updates Headcount simultaneously.

questions.text: Is the 'Financial Truth' stored in a robust system with version control, audit trails, and backup (vs. offline spreadsheets that are prone to breaking)?
questions.help: Data integrity is paramount. Robust systems protect against data loss and provide an audit trail of changes, ensuring the numbers can be trusted.

expert_action.title: Explore Predictive Analytics
expert_action.recommendation: Start with one use case: churn prediction, deal probability. Partner with data science team or use simple tools.

questions.text: Can executives clearly explain the 2-3 key drivers that determine financial success, without prompting from Finance?
questions.help: This tests alignment. When executives understand the operational levers of financial success, they can make better day-to-day decisions.

expert_action.title: Make Downside Scenarios Actionable
expert_action.recommendation: Don't just present 'what if bad.' Present 'what if bad, and here's the action plan.' Ensure action plans are owned multifunctionally, not just by Finance.

questions.text: Can Finance explain the financial outlook primarily using operational drivers (e.g., volume, churn) rather than accounting variance?
questions.help: Operational drivers are actionable; accounting variances are not. Explaining the 'why' in operational terms helps the business understand how to improve performance.

expert_action.title: Integrate External Data
expert_action.recommendation: Identify 3-5 external indicators relevant to your business. Subscribe to data feeds or track manually. Include in planning assumptions.

questions.text: Are targets dynamically adjusted based on external driver changes (e.g., inflation, commodity prices)?
questions.help: Static targets in a dynamic world lose relevance. Adjusting for external factors keeps targets fair and achievable, maintaining motivation.

expert_action.title: Link Targets to Drivers
expert_action.recommendation: Move from fixed $ targets to driver-based logic. 'If volume is X, budget is Y.' Removes the 'use it or lose it' mentality.

questions.text: Does the model automatically update revenue projections when sales pipeline stages change?
questions.help: Automating the link between sales pipeline and revenue forecast reduces manual work and ensures the forecast reflects the latest sales reality.

expert_action.title: Link CRM to Forecast
expert_action.recommendation: Connect CRM opportunities to the revenue model. Apply probability weightings based on pipeline stage (e.g., Stage 3 = 40%).

questions.text: Is the annual budget treated as just 'Forecast v1' rather than a static document?
questions.help: Treating the budget as a living document allows for adaptation. It acknowledges that assumptions change and allows the business to pivot resources as needed.

expert_action.title: Move to Continuous Planning
expert_action.recommendation: Stop 'freezing' the budget. Adopt a rolling view where the plan evolves with new information.

questions.text: Does the planning process allow for off-cycle updates to the forecast when material business events occur?
questions.help: Rigid planning cycles can miss major market shifts. Off-cycle updates ensure the forecast remains a relevant tool for decision support during volatile times.

expert_action.title: Enable Off-Cycle Adjustments
expert_action.recommendation: Create a 'light' forecast version that allows key driver updates (e.g., losing a major client) without triggering a full bottom-up cycle.

questions.text: Can the model run a 'what-if' scenario on a key driver (e.g., volume -10%) in less than an hour?
questions.help: Speed is essential for agility. If scenario analysis takes days, the opportunity to react may pass. Rapid modeling allows for real-time strategic discussions.

expert_action.title: Build Rapid Scenario Capability
expert_action.recommendation: Parameterize your model. 'Volume' should be a single input cell that flows through the entire P&L instantly.

questions.text: Are sensitivity tables standard inclusions in executive forecast reviews?
questions.help: Sensitivity analysis highlights risk. Showing how outcomes change with different assumptions prepares leadership for volatility and helps manage expectations.

expert_action.title: Add Sensitivity Analysis
expert_action.recommendation: Include a standard 'Risk & Ops' slide in every deck showing +/- 10% on key drivers.

questions.text: Do you maintain at least three live scenarios (Base, Bull, Bear) at all times?
questions.help: The future is uncertain. Maintaining multiple scenarios ensures the business is prepared for different outcomes and has thought through response plans.

expert_action.title: Maintain Multi-Scenario Model
expert_action.recommendation: Don't save-as. Build scenario toggles directly into the core model.

questions.text: Can you switch between scenarios in your reporting package with a single toggle/click?
questions.help: Easy scenario switching empowers decision-makers to compare outcomes instantly. Without it, scenario analysis becomes a back-office exercise rather than a boardroom tool.

expert_action.title: Build Scenario Toggles
expert_action.recommendation: Add a global 'Scenario' selector to your reporting dashboards. Allow users to instantly flip between Base, Upside, and Downside views.

questions.text: Does Finance stress-test models to highlight exactly what happens to cash/profit if specific variables (e.g., volume, price) drop?
questions.help: Stress testing identifies breaking points. Knowing how much volume can drop before cash runs out allows for proactive risk management.

expert_action.title: Implement Stress Testing
expert_action.recommendation: Run a 'Break the Bank' scenario quarterly. How much volume loss until we breach covenants?

questions.text: Are scenario triggers (e.g., 'If revenue drops 15%, we cut X') pre-agreed with the Board?
questions.help: Pre-agreed triggers remove emotion from crisis decision-making. Knowing exactly what actions to take when a threshold is breached enables faster response.

expert_action.title: Define Actionable Triggers
expert_action.recommendation: Pre-agree on cut lists for specific revenue thresholds. Removes emotion when the time comes.

questions.text: Does Finance have a voting seat on the committee that approves new product launches or pricing?
questions.help: Finance needs to be involved upfront to ensure commercial viability. A voting seat ensures financial implications are considered before commitments are made.

expert_action.title: Secure Seat at Approval Table
expert_action.recommendation: Insert Finance into the formal approval workflow. 'No new SKU without Finance sign-off.'

questions.text: Is Finance review mandatory for all commercial contracts that deviate from standard terms or pricing?
questions.help: Standard terms protect margin and risk. Mandatory review for deviations ensures that exceptions are financially sound and approved by the right level.

expert_action.title: Enforce Deal Desk Logic
expert_action.recommendation: Implement a 'Deal Desk' approval workflow in your CRM. Block signatures until Finance approves non-standard terms.

questions.text: Do business unit leaders proactively seek Finance advice on operational problems?
questions.help: This indicates trust. When business leaders view Finance as problem solvers rather than just scorekeepers, the partnership is working.

expert_action.title: Build Trusted Advisor Status
expert_action.recommendation: Shift conversation from 'here is your budget' to 'how can I help you hit your target?' Solve their problems, don't just police them.

questions.text: Are Finance KPIs explicitly linked to the company's top 3 strategic initiatives?
questions.help: Alignment ensures Finance is tracking what matters most. Linking KPIs to strategy focuses the function on driving the company's long-term goals.

expert_action.title: Link KPIs to Strategy
expert_action.recommendation: Don't just track Revenue. Track 'Revenue from New Product X' if that is the strategy. Mirror the corporate scorecard.

questions.text: Does Finance communicate a profitability ranking of business streams/customers to make it clear where money is actually made?
questions.help: Not all revenue is equal. Ranking profitability highlights where resources should be invested and where they might be wasted.

expert_action.title: Join Cross-Functional Planning
expert_action.recommendation: Ensure planning is a cross-functional activity (e.g., S&OP or similar)—not an isolated finance exercise. Bring financial lens to operational decisions.

questions.text: Does the CFO present a 'State of the Business' strategic view at every Board meeting?
questions.help: The CFO should tell the financial story, not just read the numbers. A strategic view provides context and forward-looking insights that the Board needs.

expert_action.title: Elevate Board Reporting
expert_action.recommendation: Move the 'Finance Update' to the start of the meeting. Focus on strategic implications of the numbers, not just the variance.

questions.text: When the CFO presents to the board, are the numbers aligned with what other executives cite?
questions.help: Conflicting numbers destroy credibility. Alignment ensures the management team is speaking with one voice and data source.

expert_action.title: Explore Statistical Forecasting
expert_action.recommendation: Start simple: time series analysis on revenue. Use tools like Prophet if you have data science capabilities.

questions.text: Are all capital investments or unbudgeted initiatives above a defined threshold required to have a formal business case with calculated ROI/NPV?
questions.help: Requiring a business case enforces discipline. It ensures that capital is deployed only to projects with a clear financial return and strategic fit.

expert_action.title: Enforce Investment Logic
expert_action.recommendation: Require a standard 1-page business case for all significant spend. Must include NPV, payback period, and strategic alignment.

questions.text: Does Finance perform post-investment reviews ('look-backs') on major projects to validate if the promised ROI was actually delivered?
questions.help: Look-backs create accountability. They verify if the benefits promised in the business case were realized and provide learning for future investments.

expert_action.title: Conduct ROI Look-Backs
expert_action.recommendation: Schedule a review 6-12 months post-investment. Compare actuals vs. the business case. Learn from the variance.

questions.text: Are reports primarily visual (charts/trends) rather than tabular data dumps?
questions.help: Visuals communicate trends faster than tables. Good visualization helps non-financial stakeholders grasp the key messages quickly.

expert_action.title: Switch to Visual Reporting
expert_action.recommendation: Adopt the '5-second rule'. If a user can't understand the trend in 5 seconds, it's a bad chart. Use waterfalls and trend lines.

questions.text: Can Finance instantly drill down from the P&L to transaction-level detail (customer/SKU) without running a new offline manual report?
questions.help: Drill-down capability turns static reports into interactive insights. Without it, answering 'why' questions requires manual queries that slow decision-making.

expert_action.title: Integrate Transactional Data
expert_action.recommendation: Connect your BI tool directly to the ERP sub-ledgers. Don't rely on summarized GL exports.

questions.text: Do dashboards allow users to drill down from summary to transaction level without asking Finance?
questions.help: Self-service empowers the business. It allows users to answer their own questions immediately, reducing the ad-hoc query burden on Finance.

expert_action.title: Implement Self-Service BI
expert_action.recommendation: Deploy a BI tool (Power BI, Tableau) connected to your data. Train budget owners to answer their own 'what happened' questions.

questions.text: Can non-finance leaders access their real-time spend vs. budget without emailing Finance?
questions.help: Real-time access encourages ownership. When leaders can see their spend status anytime, they are better equipped to manage their own budgets.

expert_action.title: Deploy Manager Self-Service
expert_action.recommendation: Give budget owners read-access to the planning tool or a curated dashboard. Stop being the gatekeeper of basic data.

questions.text: Does Finance use any automated algorithmic forecasting (e.g., machine learning) to validate human inputs?
questions.help: Algorithms provide an unbiased baseline. Using them to challenge human inputs helps identify sandbagging or over-optimism in the forecast.

expert_action.title: Pilot Algorithmic Forecasting
expert_action.recommendation: Run a simple regression model on historical sales parallel to your manual forecast. Investigate large deviations.

questions.text: Does Finance explicitly track and communicate systematic forecast bias (optimism/conservatism)?
questions.help: Bias tracking improves accuracy. Identifying if a team is consistently optimistic or conservative allows for better calibration of future forecasts.

expert_action.title: Track Forecast Accuracy
expert_action.recommendation: Measure forecast vs. actual each month. Track bias (consistently high or low?) and absolute error. Share with leadership.

questions.text: Does the system automatically flag forecast outliers based on historical trends?
questions.help: Automated checks catch errors early. Flagging outliers saves review time and prevents unrealistic numbers from entering the consolidated plan.

expert_action.title: Automate Outlier Detection
expert_action.recommendation: Implement statistical rules (e.g., +/- 2 standard deviations) to flag anomalies in user submissions before they roll up.

questions.text: Are standard journal entries automated?
questions.help: Automation reduces manual error and effort. Recurring entries should be set to run automatically, freeing up time for higher-value activities.

expert_action.title: Automate Standard JEs
expert_action.recommendation: Configure recurring journals for rent, depreciation, and standard accruals. Remove manual touchpoints.

questions.text: Is the bank reconciliation process >90% automated?
questions.help: High automation rates in reconciliation indicate efficient processes. Manual matching should be the exception, not the rule.

expert_action.title: Automate Bank Recs
expert_action.recommendation: Connect bank feeds to ERP. Configure auto-matching rules for 90% of transaction volume.

questions.text: Has Finance deliberately stopped or automated recurring reports to free up capacity?
questions.help: Stopping low-value work is as important as starting new work. Regularly pruning reports frees up capacity for analysis and strategic support.

expert_action.title: Insert Finance into Pricing
expert_action.recommendation: Create pricing guardrails: minimum margins, discount approval levels. Provide Sales with a simple tool showing deal profitability.

questions.text: Are transactional finance roles (AP/AR) centralized or outsourced to lower-cost centers?
questions.help: Centralization drives efficiency. Grouping transactional roles allows for standardization and economies of scale, often reducing cost.

expert_action.title: Create Strategic Capacity
expert_action.recommendation: Audit time spent on BAU (Business As Usual) vs. strategic. Target: 70/30 split. Automate or eliminate low-value BAU work.

questions.text: Are Finance Business Partners measured on the performance of their supported units?
questions.help: Shared KPIs create alignment. When Finance partners share the goals of their business unit, they are more motivated to drive operational success.

expert_action.title: Shared Performance KPIs
expert_action.recommendation: Link Finance bonus to the P&L of the unit they support. Align incentives.

questions.text: Is there a formal Service Level Agreement (SLA) between the business and the finance processing team?
questions.help: SLAs set expectations. They define what the business can expect in terms of speed and quality, reducing friction and clarifying accountability.

expert_action.title: Implement Finance Retrospectives
expert_action.recommendation: Run a retrospective after each close and budget cycle (Kaizen). What worked? What didn't? Pick one improvement per cycle.

questions.text: Are there defined response times for key finance services (e.g., ad-hoc analysis, AP inquiries) that the business relies on?
questions.help: Defined response times manage expectations. They ensure the business knows when they will get an answer, which improves planning and trust.

expert_action.title: Publish Finance SLAs
expert_action.recommendation: Define and track turnaround times for common requests (e.g., '24 hours for AP queries'). Publish performance to the business.
